newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany now more attractive for business - Opel.
newsitem.headline: Germany now more attractive for business - Opel.

text.p: David Herman, chief executive of General Motors Co's German unit Adam Opel AG, said recent developments in Germany were making it increasingly more attractive as a place to invest.

"The situation in Germany has significantly improved compared to its western neighbours," Herman was quoted as saying in an interview published in the Friday edition of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung newspaper.

Herman said the recent softening of the mark, low inflation and an improved dialogue with workers and unions all added to Germany's traditional advantages, which included a good market and an environment favourable to the realisation of business projects.
Such factors, he said, had played a role in Opel's decision to produce its new diesel engine in its German Kaiserslautern plant. "We could have built that anywhere in the world."

Herman nonetheless bemoaned the continued high level of non-wage labour costs in Germany and what he called rigid labour laws that, for example, make employing people on a temporary basis more difficult.
